div.p:
The cattle in rushing along to the water
in the Mababe probably crossed a small
patch of of ˄ trees containing Tsetse an insect which was
shortly to become a perfect pest to us -
Shobo had found his way to the
Bayeiye and now appeared when
we came up to the river with
at the head ofof a party of them and as he wished to
shewshow his importance before his
friends he walked up boldly
and commanded our whole
cavalcade to stop - & to bring upforth
fire and tobacco while he
coolly sat down and smoked
his pipe - It was such an inimitably
natural way of shewingshowing off ˄ that we
all stopped to admire the acting
and though wehe had left us
at last, we all loved Shobo
a wonderful fine specimen
of that wonderful people the
Bushmen -

Next day we came to a village
of Banajoa a tribe which
extends far to the Eastward
They were living on the borders
of a marsh in which the
X Mababe terminates - they had
lost their crop of corn (Caffer sorghum)
and now subsided almost
entirely on the root called
X "Tsitla", a kind of aroidorioeaaroidoea which
contains a very large quantity of
159 162
sweet tasted starch - When dried
and pounded into meal and
allowed to ferment it is to
an unpleasant food - The
women shave off all the hair
of their heads and seemed
darker than the Bechuanas
Their huts were built on poles
and a fire is made beneath
in order that the smoke
may drive away the mosquitoes
which abound on the Mababe
and Tamunakle more
than in any other part of
the country - The headman
of this village Majane seemed
seemed a little wanting in
ability but had ˄ had wit enough
to promote a younger member
of the family to the office - This
person the most like the
ugly negro of the tobacconists'
shops I ever saw was called
Moroa Majane or son of Majane
and proved an active
guide through the river
Sonta and to the banks of
the Chobe in the country
of Sebituane - We had
come through another tsetse
district by night and our
passed over our cattle to
the Northern bank to preserve
them from its ravages -

160 163 75
A few remarks on the Tsetse,
glossina morsitans may here be appropriate - It is
not much larger than the
common house fly and nearly
of the same brown colour as
the common honey bee - The after
part of the body has three or four
yellow bars accross it - The
wings project beyond this
part considerably and it is
remarkably alert, alvoiding
most dexterously all attempts
to capture it with the hand
at common temperatures,
In the cool of the mornings &
evenings it is less agile - Its
peculiar buzbuzz when once heard
can never be forgotten by
the traveller whose means
of locomotion are domestic
animals, for it is well
known that the bite of this
poisonous insect is
certain death to the ox - horse
and dog - In this journey
though we were not certainaware
of any great number ˄ having at
any time lightinged on our
cattle we lost forty three head
fine oxen ˄ by its bite - We watched them
carefully and believe that
not a score of flies were
ever upon them -

A most remarkable
161 164
feature in the bite is its perfect
harmlessness in man and
wild animals and even
calves so long as they continue
to suck the cows - We
lived two months in its habitat
which was in this case
as sharply defined as in
many others for the south
bank of the Chobe was
infested by it and the
Northern bank where our
cattle were
placed only 50 ydsyards
distant contained not a
single specimen - This was
the more remarkable as we
often saw natives carrying
over raw meat to the
opposite bank with many
tsetse settled upon it -
The person does not seem
injected by a sting or by ova
placed beneath the skin
for when one is allowed
to settle on the hand - it is
seen to insert the middle prong
of three portions into which the proboscis
divides itself; somewhat deeply
into the true skin: it then
draws withdraws it ˄ out a little way
and it assumes a crimson
colour as the mandibles
come into brisk operation -
The previously The before ˄ shrunken belly
swells out and though
perfectly undisturbed the fly
162 165
quietly leavesdeparts when it is full -
A littleslight itchiness and irritation
follows but not more than
in the bite of a mosquito -
In the ox this same bite produces
no more immediate effects
than in man - It does not
startle him as the gadfly does
but a few days afterwards
the following symptoms
supervene - The eye ˄ & nose - begins
to run, the coat stares as
if the animal were cold -
A swelling appears under
the jaw and sometimes at
the navel, and though the
animal continues to graze
emaciation commences
accompanied with a
peculiar flaccidity of the
muscles, and it proceeds
unchecked untilluntil perhaps
months afterwards, purging
comes on and the animal
no longer able to graze
perishes in a state of extreme
exhaustion - Those which are
in good condition often
perish with staggering ˄ & blindness as if
the brain were affectinged soon
after the bite is infected -
Sudden changes of temperature
produced by falls of rain
seem to hasten the progress
of the complaint, but in
163 166
but in general the emaciation
goes on uninterrupted for
months and do what we
will they perish miserably -

When opened the cellular
tissue on the surface of the
body beneath the skin is
seen to be injected with
air, as if a quantity of
soap bublesbubbles were scattered
over it or an dishonest
ackwardawkward butcher had been
trying to make it look fat.
The fat is of a greenish yellow
colour and oily consistence
All the muscles are flabby &
the heart often so soft the
fingers may be made to
meet through it- The lungs
and liver partake of the
disease - The stomach and
bowels are pale and empty
and the gall bladder is distended
with bile -

These symptoms seem
to indicate what is probably
the case, a poison in the
blood - the germ of which
enters when the proboscis
is inserted to draw blood -
Another insect will be
mentioned in which this
same operation produces
in the human subject both
vomiting and purging
164 167
In this case the poison germ however
minute in quantity seems
capable of reproducing itself
for the blood at death is
very small in quantity
and scarcely stains the hands
in dissection

The Mule, ass - and goat
enjoy the same immunity
as man and the game -
Many large tribes in the
ZambesiZambezi lands can keep
no domestic animals
except the goat in consequence
of the scourge existing in
their country - Our children
were frequently bitten yet
suffered no harm - and
we saw around us
numbers herds of Zebras - buffaloes
pigs, pallahs & other antelopes,
feeding quietly in the very
habitat of the tsetse, yet
as undisturbed by its bite
as oxen are when they
recievereceived the fatal poison
There is not so much
difference in the natures
of the horse & Zebra -
The buffalo & ox - The
sheep and antelope - as
to afford any satisfactory
explanation of the phenomenon
Is a man not as much
a domestic animal as a dog?
165 168 80
The curious feature in the case
that dogs ˄ perish though fed on milk (as the
calves which escape) which
so long as they continue suckling
made us imagine that it
the mischief might be produced by some
plant in the locality but
Major Captain Frank Vardon
of the Madras army had
settled that point by riding
a horse up to a small
hill infested by the insect
and though he only remained
long enough to take a view
of the country and catch
some specimens from the
of tsetse on the animal
in ten days afterwards the
horse was dead -

The well known disgust
which the tsetse shewsshows to
animal excreta as exhibited
when a village settles is placed
in its habitat has been
observed and acted on byturned to
account by some of the doctors - They
mixuse droppings of animals
human milk & some medicines
together and smear the animals
that are aboutintended to pass through a
tsetse district - but this though
it proves a preventative at
the time is not permanent
There is no cure ˄ yet known
for the disease - - A careless
166 169
herd allowing a large number
of cattle to wander intointo a
tsetse district loses all except
the calves, and Sebituane
once lost nearly the entire
cattle of his tribe - very many
thousands, by unwittingly
coming into under its influence
Inno-culationInoculation does not produceinsure
immunity as animals which
have been slightly bitten in
one year may perish by
61 a [greater number of bites in
the next - But it is probable
that with the increase of guns
the game will perish as in
the South and the Tsetse
deprived of food perish
become extinct simultaneously
with the larger animals

The Makololo whom we
met on the Chobe were delighted
to meet us - And as their chief
Sebituane was about twenty
miles down the river Mr O - Oswell
and I proceeded in canoes
to his temporary residence
He had come from the Barotse
town of Naliele down to
Sesheke as soon as he heard
of white men being in search
of him, and now came
167 170
one hundred miles more to bid
us welcome into his country -
ThHey wereas upon an island with
all his principal men around
him - and engaged in singing ˄
when we arrived It was more like church music
than the sing-song ēēē ae ae ae - of
the Bechuanas in the South and
they continued the tune for
some seconds after we approach
We informed him After mentioning ourof the difficulties
we had encountered, and how glad we were that
they were all over comeat an end by
at last reaching his presence
He signified his own joy
and added "your cattle are
all bitten by the tsetse and
will certainly die - but never
mind, I have oxen and will
give you as many as you
need" - We in our ignorance
then thought ˄ that as so few tsetse
had bitten them no great
mischief would follow
He presented us with an ox ˄
and a jar of honey as food and handed us over
to the care of Mahale who had
headed the party to Kolobeng &
would now fain take ˄ appropriate to himself the
whole credit of their ˄ our coming
to himself - Prepared skins of
oxen as soft as cloth were
given to cover us through
the night and as nothing
168 171
could isbe returned to this chief Mahale
became honourowner of them too -
Long before it was day Sebituane
came and sitting down by
the fire which was lighted
behind the hedge where we
lay for our benefit he
began and narrated his
own difficulties in crossing
that same desert we had
mastered long afterwards
As he had been most
remarkable in his carreer
and was unquestionably
the greatest man in all
that country, I may give
a short sketch of his life -
may prove interesting to the reader.

He seemed about 45 years
of age - of a tall & wiry form
and slightly bald - In manner
cool and collected and more
frank in his answers
than any chief I ever met
He was the greatest warrior
ever heard of beyond the
colony for unlike MosilikatzMosilikatse
and Dingaan &c - he always
led his men into battle himself
When he saw the enemy
he felt the edge of his battle
axe and said "Aha! it is sharp
and whoever turns his back
on the enemy will feel its edge" -

169 172
So fleet of foot was he ˄ that all his
people knew there was no escape
for the coward He wasas any such would be cut
down without
mercy - - In some
instances of skulking he
allowed the individual to
return home - Then calling
him, he would say - "Ah, you
prefer dying at home to
dying in the field ˄ do you?, you
shall have your desire" this
was the signal for his
immediate execution - This discipline
will explain what follows

He came from the sources
of the Likwa & Namagari in
the South - so we met him
800 or 900 ˄ miles from his
birth place - He was not the son
of a chief though related closely
to the reigning family of
the BasutaBasutu and when
in an attack by Sikonyele
the tribe was driven out of
one part Sebituane was one
in that immense horde of
savages driven back by
the Griquas ˄ from Kuruman in 1824 * He
then fled to the North with
an insignificant party of
men and cattle - At Kolobeng
Melita the BangwaketzeBangwaketse collected
the Bakwains - Bakatla and
Bahurutse to eat him up
* See an account of this affair
in MoffatsMoffat's Missionary enterprise
in Africa
170 173 85
Placing his men in front
and ˄ the women behind the cattle
he routed the whole ˄ of his enemies at one blow Having thus
conquered Makabe
the chief of the Bangwak^etseBangwaketse
and sat himself
down in MakabesMakabe's
town he took
immediate possession
of that chief's
town and
all his goods
He then afterwards settled at # Sebituane
subsequently
settled at the
place called Litubaruba
and ˄ his people suffered ˄ severely in one of those
unheard of attacks by two
white men in which murder
QuQuery meaning is committed and materials
laid up in the conscience
for a future judgment -
# A great variety of fortune
followed him in the Northern
part of the Bechunana country
Twice he lost all his cattle
by attacks of the MatibeleMatebele but
always kept his people
together and retook more than
he lost - He ˄ then crossed the desert
inby nearly the same path that
we did, ^ His captured
guide however
fled from
him while
travelling
by night - conquered all
the tribes along the Zouga
and at Lake Nyassa and
hearing that
He had captured a guide &
as it was necessary to
travel by night in order
to reach water the guide
took advantage of this and gave him the slip; and
after marching till morning
and going as they thought
right they found themselves
coming on the trail of the
day before - He found the
171 174
Many of his cattle burst away
from him in the frenzy
of thirst and rushed back
to Serotli (then a large water)
and to Mashüe and Lopepe
the habitations of their original
owners - He refurnishedstocked
himself among the Batletli
on Lake Kumadau - who
had their herds of the large
horned species of cattle * * Note
We found the
Batauana
in possession
of this breed
when we dis-
covered Lake
Ngami
HeConquering all around the
Lake Ngami he heard of
white men living at the
wWest coast and haunted
by what seems to have been
haunted him during his
through the dream of his whole life ˄ a desire to have
the intercourse ofwith the white
man he passed away to
the South west into the parts
opened up lately by Messers
Galton and Anderson
There suffering intensely
from thirst they ^ he & his party came
to a small well - He
decided that the men not
the cattle should drink it
the former being of most
value as they could fight
for more3 should these be
lost - In the morning they
found the cattle had escaped
to the Damarás

172 175
Returning to the North poorer
than he left -^ started He ascended
the Teoughe to the Hill Sorila
and crossed over a swampy
country to the Eastwards
The low lying basin of the
Leeambye presented no
attractions to a pastoral tribe
like his so he moved down
that river among the Bashubia
and Batōka who were then
living in all their glory
His narrative resembles
closely the "Commentaries
of Caesar - " and ˄ the History of ^ the British
in India, He was always
forced to attack the different
tribes and to this day his men
justify every step he took as
perfectly just and right - The
Batoka lived onon large islands
in the Leeambye or Zambezi
and feeling perfectly secure
in their fastnesses often
allured fugitive or wandering
tribes on to uninhabited
islets on pretence of ferrying
them accrossacross - and there left
them to perish for the sake
of their goods - Sekomi the
chief of the Bamangwato was when a child in danger
of meeting this fate but a
man still living had compassion
on him & enabled his mother
173 176
to escape ˄ with him by night - The river
is so large that the clearestsharpest
eye cannot tell the difference
the between an island and a
bend of the opposite bank
But Sebituane with his
usual foresight requested
the island chief who ferried
him accross to take his
seat in the canoe with
him and detained him by
his side till all his people
and cattle were safely landed
The whole Batoka country
was then densely peopled
and they had a curious foible
weakness for of ornamenting their villages
with the skulls of strangers
When he appeared near the
great falls - an immense army
collected to make trophies
of the Makololo skulls - but
instead of that they gave him
a good excuse of for conquering
them and capturing so many
cattle that his people were
quite incapable of taking
any note of the sheep and
goats - He overran all the
high lands towards the Kafue
and settled in what is called
a pastoral country - short grass
little forest and gently undulating
plains - The Makololo have
174 177
never lost their love for this
fine healthy spot -

But the MatibeleMatebele a Kaffir
or Zulau tribe under MosilikatzeMosilikatse crossed
the ZambesiZambezi and attacking
him in this chosen spot captured
his cattle and women - Rallying
his men he followed and
recaptured the whole - A fresh
attack was repulsed again
and Sebituane thought of
going farther down the
ZambesiZambezi to the country
of the white men - He had an
idea whence imbibed I
never could learn that if
he had a cannon he
might live in peace - He
had ˄ led ^ a life of war yet no one
apparently desired peace
more than he did - A prophet
induced led him to turn his face
again to the Westward - This
man by name Tlapane was
called a "senoga" one who holds
intercourse with the gods - He
probably had a smacktouch of insanity
for he was in the habit of retiring
no one knew whither but probably
into some cave to remain in the
hypnotic state for untilluntil the moon
was full - Then returning to the
tribe quite emaciated ˄ he worked himself
as other do into awho pretend to the
prophetic afflatus untilluntil he was
175 178 90
in a state of exstasyecstacy - They ˄ These pretended prophets commence
their operations it by violent action of the voluntary
muscles - stamping ˄ & leaping shouting in
a peculiarly violent manner or
beating the ground with a club
They pretend that theseir utterances are
unknown to themselves - Tlapane
pointing Eastwards said - "There Sebituane
I behold a fire - shun it - It is a fire
which will burn youmay scorch thee - The gods
say - "go not thither" Then turning
to the West he said - "I see a city
and a nation of black men - men
of the water - their cattle are red - Your
Thine own tribe ˄ Sebituane is perishing and will
be consumed - youthou wilt govern
black men and when your
thy warriors have captured red
cattle then let not the owners
be killed, they are yourthy future
tribe - They are yourthy city let them
be spared to buildto cause you up - " thee to build"
"And thou RamosininiRamosinii Thy
village will perish utterly" - If
Mokari removes from that village
he will perish first, and thou
RamosininiRamosinii wilt be the last to
die - Concerning himself he
added" "The gods have caused other
men to drink water but to me
QuQuery say
the water they have given the urine ˄ bitter water of the
Chukuru (Rhinoceros) (meaning bitter
bad water) They call me away
myself - I cannot stay much
longer with you - "
176 179
This utterance which ˄ loses much
in the translation I have given
rather fully ˄ as it shewsshows an observant
mind - The policy recommended
was wise and the and the deaths
of the "senoga" and those of the two
men and their d with the erasementdestruction
of their village, having all
happened soon after, it is not
wonderful that Sebituane
followed implicitly the warning
voice - The black men
referred to were the Barotse
or as they term themselves
Baloiana; and Sebituane
spared their chiefs even though
they attacked him first -
At Though hHe had ascended the
Barotse valley, he ˄ but was followed
by MatibeleMatebele as MosilikatzeMosilikatse
never could forgive the
former defeats - They came
up the river in a very large
body - Sebituane placed some
goats on one of the large islands
of the Zambezi as a bait
to the warriors and some
men in canoes to assist
his enemiesthem - When they were
all on the island the canoes
were removed and the
MatibeleMatebele found themselves
completely in a trap and
perfectly unable to swim
they subsisted some time
on the roots of grass after the
177 180
after the goats were gone but
gradually became so emaciated
that when the Makololo landed
they had only to perform the part
of executioners on the adults &
incorporate the rest into their own
tribe - Sebit MosilikatzeMosilikatse was
goaded on by his warriors to
revenge this loss - so he sent
an immense army carrying
canoes ˄ with them that no such mishap
might occur again - Sebituane
had by this time incorporated
the Barotse and taught his
young men to manage canoes
so he went from island
to island and watched the
MatibeleMatebele so that they could not
use their canoes without
parting their forces. At last
all the Makalolo and their
cattle were collected on the
island of Loyelo - And they
lay all around keeping
watch night and day
over the enemy - After some
time spent in this way
Sebituane went in a canoe
towards them and addressing
them by an interpreter asked
why they wished to kill him
he had never attacked them
never harmed their chief
"Au! the guilt is on your side"
178 181
the MatibeleMatebele made no reply but
the Makololo next day saw
their canoes lying smashed
They returned towards their
own country and fever and
famine and the Batoka did
the rest completed their
destruction - only five men returned
to MosilikatzeMosilikatse

Sebituane He had now not only con-
quered all the black tribes
over an immense tract
of country; but made himself
dreaded by the terrible MosilikatzeMosilikatse
He never could trust himthis
ferocious chief, however -
And as the chiefs on the
islands had been guilty of
ferrying his enemies
accrossacross the Zambezi
he made a rapid descent
down upon them and
roouted them all out of their
fastnesses - He thus unwittingly
performed a good service
to the country by breaking
completely ˄ breaking down the whol old
system which prevented
trade from penetrating into
the great valley - Of the
chiefs who escaped he said
"they love MosilikatzeMosilikatse, let
them live with him - The
ZambesiZambezi is my line of
defence" and men were
placed all along it as sentinels
179 182
When he heard of our wish to
visit him - he did all he could
to assist our approach -
Sechele - Sekomi and Lechulatebe
owed their lives to his clemency
and the latter might have paid
dearly for his obstructiveness
He knew everything that
happened in the country
for Sebituane had the art
of gaining the affections
of both of his own people and
of strangers - When a party
of poor men came to sell
their hoes or skins no matter
how ungainly they might
be he knew them all - And
never did a stranger depart
from him without some
token of his generosity -
A party of the poor sitting
far apart from the
Makololo gentlemen around
the chief, would be sur-
-prised to see him coming
alone to them and sitting
down enquire if they were
hungry - He would order
an attendant to bring meal
and milk and honey - and
mixing them in their sight
make them feast perhaps
for the first time in their lives
on a lordly dish - They ˄ were delighted
180 183 95
beyond measure with his affabi-
-lity and liberality, felt their hearts
warm ^ towards him and gave him all
the information in their power
and as he never allowed a
party of strangers to go away
without giving everone of
them ^ servants and all each a present his praises
were sounded far & wide
"He has a heart - He is wise" were
the usual expressions we
heard before we saw him - He
was much pleased with
the proof of confidence we
had shewnshown in bringing our
children - and promised to
take us to see his country
so that we might choose
whatever part we might like
to locate ourselves ^ in - Our plan
was that I should remain
in the pursuit of my objects
as a missionary while
Mr OswelOswell should explore
the ZambesiZambezi to the East - Poor
Sebituane however just
after realizing what he
had so long ardently desired
fell sick of inflammation
of the lungs - which extended
from an old wound got
at Melita - I saw his danger
but being a stranger feared
to treat him lest in the event
of his death I should be
181 184 96
blamed by his people - I mentioned
that to one of his doctors he
said "your fear is prudent &
wise" "this people would blame
you" - He had been cured the
during the year before by the Barotse
making a large number
of free incisions in the
chest - The Makololo doctors
scarcely cut the skin - On
the afternoon in which he
died I visited him when
the service was over with
my little boy Robert - "Come
near said Sebituane &
see if I am any longer
a man - I am done" After
sitting with him some time
I rose to depart when
the dying chieftain raised
himself up a little from
his prone position, called
a servant and said "Take
Robert to Maunku (one
of his wives) and tell her
to give him some milk"
These were histhe last words
ever spoken by Sebituane

We were not informed
till next day of his death
Their burial of a Bechuana
chief takes place in his cattle
pen - and all the cattle are
driven for an hour or two
around & over the grave so
